Title: Craig D. Devenport
Comment:
I am the President of a relatively small Air Charter Operation owning and operating 7 Airtaxi aircraft.

Simply put, the plethora of new mandates promulgated by the regulating agency, and Congress that must be adheared to and accomplished by our industry within a relatively short period has a devestating financial effect on operators, especially those that  have invested the most in their companies and  own all the aircraft they operate.
Each upcoming requirement in itself has a significant impact on the Air Taxi industry, cumulatively, they will destroy many smaller employers, and cause a great many lost jobs.

We simply cannot continue to pay for one government mandate after another. We have for instance one Lear 35A, that will be subject to the following costly mandates in short order:  TSA, RSVM, Increased Customs Bond Requirements, Ground Proximity Warning Equipment, and Collision Avoidance Equipment.  Total Cost of Compliance?  including downtime..easily $500,000.
Now, our company is a 14 year old Part 135 operation, and has a perfect safety record.  The only results I believe we will see in all of this is losss of customers during the extensive downtimes for installations, and an inability to justify the investment, hence our exit from turbine operations.  
Just how long does the federal government estimate it will take a small company like mine to recoup $500,000 in this industry?, for a single aircraft?  I'll tell you how long... about 10 years to break even, and that's in the unlikely event that no more costly regulatory mandates are forced upon our industry.  
I understand that we may be able to operate below 29,000 ft and above 40,000 ft...first, operating costs at lower altitudes are prohibitive.
There are not many flight levels above the bracketed altitudes, and the lengths of many trips would make climbing all the way thru the 30's impractical.  Further, the result of this propsal is going to have the opposite effect of that hoped for.  Traffic will be compressed below 30,000 ft creating a much greater degree of congestion in the 20-29 flight levels, and constant requests for altitudes in the upper 20's that will not be able to be fullfilled due to saturation....causing turbine operators such as us to have to fly at even lower FL's where operation becomes economiclly unfeasible while at the same time requiring a much greater workload on ATC, and much greater delays in the system. 
I see this proposal as it stands as a lose lose proposition for employers in the industry, their employees, the safety of the traveling public  who aren't priveledged to use the bracketed FL's and ATC with increased workload, and delays caused by saturation at various flight levels.
Further, technology, I believe, is advanced enough to maintain reduced seperation today, without the neccessity of the installation of such expensive equipment...and with the already mandated Collision Avoidance equipment required for the cockpit, safety margins should be enhanced.

This proposal is so strongly supported by the Airlines, who fly established routes on a repeated basis because  they see it as a means to remove traffic from their prefered FL's and reducing their delays. What about the rest of us?  This is a classic example of robbing Peter to pay Paul. We will reduce delays and congestion at certain FL's only to increase them at others.   
Obviously, General Aviation and on demand Aircharter would stand to benefit the most from the free flight concept. However the cost of taking advantage of it makes it unfeasible. 

The net effect in all of this is going to be negligible for the system, and extremely costly to the operator, unless or until a system is developed that will allow this activity at a cost to operators that is economiclly feasible enough to allow them to take advantage of it. 
I'm sure that the major corporations, the time share aircraft industry, and Warren Buffet can afford this.
Those of us who have struggled to grow our businesses over years, investing every penny back into them to grow them are being devestated by this never ending parade of rule making mandating extremely expensive, and safety negligible requirements.  I fear that in all of this, all we will do is cause aircrews to have their heads stuck evermore in a downward position in the cockpit, relying more and more on technological means for safety, rather than good advanced planning, good judgement, human control, and observation.
We are creating a system designed to the lowest common denominator....and we will create an atmosphere that encourages performance to that level.  Systems malfunction, and they cause people to become lax in their preperation, planning and vigilance.  When a situation presents itself hesitation will become a problem...."gee my system doesn't show that conflict". Air transportation is the safest system of travel in the world....as we move farther and farther from reliance on well trained individuals constantly honing judgement and reaction skills....and the absolute neccessity for thorough advanced planning, we will create a whole new set of problems for ourselves.  Redundancy is smart.  Relying on it as a crutch is not...the human condition is such that once relied upon, systems become a crutch, and a rationale to cut corners in many peoples minds.
We have nearly eliminated accidents in turbine aircraft...we will NEVER eliminate them all together. The sheer addition of complex system after complex system is a threat to safety in itself.

No one has more systems, more redundancy, and more monitoring capability than NASA....how does their overall safety record stack up to turbine aircraft operations on ratio basis?
How complex do we intend to make our on board systems?  How much can people be expected to monitor, before some of the critical safety duties of the crew begin to suffer, at the expense of others less likely to present conflict on a frequent basis?
I urge the Agency to drop this proposal until such time as a system can be developed that is not cost prohbitive to operators, and economiclly unfeasible. 
We will not solve any problems overall going down this road, and that is what our goal needs to be.  The concept is outstanding, the potential enormus, the plan as it stands however is not affordable...we need systems that require lower cost operator investment.  We can't give up 3 years margin, for every proposal that comes along, you now have us up to 10 years.  This is nonsensical.

Pending mandates should be judged with the cumulative burden promulgated on the Indusrtry over a 10 year period, including all other mandates proposed or already approved over the period, regardless of the agency proposing the burden. Looking at each proposals economic burden independently DOES NOT present the true picture of the consequences we are causing ourselves economiclly.  None ever seem totally devestating in themselves...cumulative impact presents a whole other story. 
We will eventually eliminate the small business sector from this industry...the day is not that far away.  Perhaps that is the goal.  
Enough is enough. 

Respectfully Submitted,
Craig Devenport, president
West Bend Air, Inc.

Title: Travel Agents of America
Comment:
To: Travel Agents of America:  READ AND HEAD EVERY WORD OF THIS CALL-TO-ACTION IF YOU PLAN ON STAYING IN THE TRAVEL AGENT INDUSTRY!!!

From: Lawton Roberts

Subject: AIRFARE PRICE DISCRIMINATION, WEB-ONLY AIRFARES VERSUS CRS AIRFARES

On December 11th, I sent out a call-to-action to travel agents in over 30 states who had registered on the website www.TravelAgentsofAmerica.com asking them to submit specific examples of airfare disparities between prices quoted in CRS's and prices quoted on the same itinerary in airline website data bases such as delta.com, ual.com, nwa.com, aa.com, and orbitz.com.  This new call-to-action was based on a very enlightening meeting I had in Washington with the U. S. Department of Transportation in early December.  Now, on February 6, 2002, I am repeating this call to action, with one significant difference.  From now until the proposed revisions to the CRS regulations are published by the DOT in March, 2002, this specific call-to-action needs to be an on-going effort by all travel agents.  In football, it's called PILING ON!!!  Every time you or your staff encounters a specific example of fare disparity, whether it is first identified by your staff or one of your customers, you need to take the time to print all screens from all data sources and send it in to the DOT, per the instructions that follow.  This can be a weekly mailing of all such examples compiled during the week.  Simply prepare your cover letter once, and reuse it with a current date each time you send your examples to the DOT.  This material is definitely reaching the proper authorities, and is being considered in the revisions that are now underway to the CRS Regulations that are long overdue for rewrite.  The more examples you can provide together with your own concerns about this discriminatory and predatory impact on your business, the better our industry's chances of having this particular problem corrected by the DOT in 2002, through regulatory means.  Through my numerous trips to Washington on behalf of travel agents, I have been advised by both Senate and House counsel familiar with this problem that the DOT has the authority under existing law to correct this problem through regulatory means, without the need for any new legislation.  And the CRS regulations are the logical place to deal with it. By simply classifying Orbitz as a CRS, as Canada's Transport Union has done, this problem would be corrected, since under existing DOT regulations in the United States, airfares provided by the airlines to one CRS must also be provided to all other CRS's.

BACKGROUND TO THIS CALL-TO-ACTION:  For those who are new to Travel Agents of America, let me give you some background that led to the need for this specific action on your part.  In my meeting with the DOT in early December, I learned that the DOT had sent out what is known as an ANPRM in 1997, (Advanced Notice of Proposed Rule Making), to invite input to possible changes to the federal regulations that govern CRS's.  I knew that there had been much trade press written about CRS rule changes several years ago, but it had seemed to just go nowhere.  I was advised that the new DOT administration under Secretary Mineta was the reason that finally rewriting the CRS regulations had suddenly become a priority.  The DOT representatives advised me that one of the issues they were considering addressing was the issue of web fares that are excluded from CRS databases, the implications on the public, travel agents and airlines.  I informed them that Expedia had just fought for and received a favorable ruling from the European Union on web fares in the European community that were about to be in the European equivalent of Orbitz, Oboto.  Now, fares offered in Oboto must be offered in travel agent databases through CRS's as well.  I also advised them that the Canadian Transport Union had ruled that fares offered in Orbitz would also have to be offered in CRS's to Canadian Travel Agencies.  Orbitz is not yet available on line to the public in Canada, so I am told.  So web fares are not yet available to CRS subscribers in Canada.  As to the timetable for the process of CRS rulemaking and eventual implementation of any CRS rule changes, the U. S. DOT is currently in the process of rewriting the CRS regulations, and plans to publish a draft version to the public by the end of March 2002, as an NPRM, (Notice of Proposed Rule Making).  Then follows 60 days of invited comments from any and all affected parties, including travel agents, airlines, CRS's, and consumer advocates, then a final internal DOT review based on the feedback to the proposed rules, then the publication of a Final CRS Rule Change, followed by a period of allowing for all parties to make needed system or procedural changes in order to meet compliance by a certain deadline.  Optimistically, the DOT hopes to implement the revised CRS regulations by no later than the end of 2002.

Following my meeting with the DOT in December, I requested and received a favorable ruling that allows travel agents to provide individual comments or concerns about the unfair price discrimination issue NOW, although the published deadline for DOT receipt of invited comments in response to the DOT's Advanced Notice of Proposed Rule-Making had already passed.  In addition, whenever the NPRM is published this spring along with the initial version of the proposed CRS rule changes, we along with others will be invited to submit our comments again, based on the proposed revisions, whether they are favorable to travel agents or not.  I will keep you advised of this very important event and opportunity whenever it occurs.  So once again, it's time for action.  Here is your individual opportunity to express your concerns about web-only fares direct to the people in our federal government who can do something about it, and in fact are considering that very thing.  Because of Travel Agents of America, once again you have an opportunity to you're YOUR VOICE heard in Washington, unfiltered by any third party.  NOW IS THE TIME TO TAKE ACTION, AS FOLLOWS:

TRAVEL AGENTS OF AMERICA

NEW  CALL-TO-ACTION  February 6, 2002

(Even if you have participated in this call-to-action before in late December or in January, consider this a new strategy to bombard the DOT in Washington over the next several weeks with specific examples of airfare price discrimination.  Travel agency documentation on this problem that the DOT has received to date is now beginning to get serious attention and consideration during the CRS rule making process that is now underway at the DOT.  Now is the time to flood the DOT with specific examples of this serious threat to the travel agent industry.  Now is the time to PILE ON!!!)

YOUR OPPORTUNITY TO CONVEY YOUR PERSONAL CONCERNS TO THE U. S. DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION ABOUT THE IMPACT TO YOU OF THE AIRLINE PRACTICE OF AIRFARE PRICE DISCRIMINATION BY WITHHOLDING WEB-ONLY AIR FARES FROM TRAVEL AGENT CRS'S:

1.      STEP ONE:  Gather specific printed examples of airfare price discrimination comparing web-only fares quoted on airline web sites plus Orbitz plus your CRS.  Make printouts from all three sources for each example.  Label each one clearly so that anyone can easily compare the three sources of fare quotes for the same itinerary, airline, etc.  Be sure to compare base fares to base fares, as Orbitz does not break it out.  Find at least two or three examples.  I am sure you can find examples that show fare disparities of well over 20% between quotes. Recently, our agency identified a difference of 90%, or $1,500 between a CRS fare and an airline website fare.

2.      STEP TWO:  Write a cover letter on your letterhead expressing your concern about the airline practice of withholding the lowest airfares from your business, its impact both to you and to your customers, and why you believe it to be unfair competition.  Make a copy of all your correspondence and attachments, and file for possible later reference, if contacted by the DOT.  The heading of your cover letter should look something like this:

BEFORE THE 
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION
WASHINGTON, D. C.

February XX,  2002

COMMENTS OF THE
XYZ TRAVEL AGENCY, INC.
IN THE MATTER OF
DOCKET #2881, CRS RULE MAKING 

3.      Send the cover letter with your attachments by overnight courier or by U. S. Mail.  I have been assured that overnight courier services like Federal Express are getting through almost without delay.  U. S. Mail is getting through, but with some delay.  Send to:

a.      United States Department of Transportation
b.      Docket Section
c.      Reference Docket #2881, CRS Rule Making
d.      400 7th Street, SW
e.      Washington, D. C. , 20590
f.      For a phone number on the overnight air bill, use 202-366-8822
g.      For a dept, use "Docket Section"

You can expect that I will follow this entire process of CRS rulemaking over the next 12 months and that I will alert you at each opportunity to participate in it as the process allows, now that we know that such a process is underway!

I hope that every travel agent in America will take advantage of this important call-to-action.  With each new visit or phone call to Washington, I am learning more about how the process (in Washington) works and where your most productive efforts need to be focused.  But it's up to you to individually do your part in helping to make positive changes in our industry.  No longer can we sit by on the sidelines and expect someone else to deal with these critically important issues on our behalf, even if we paid them to.

Please tell other travel agents in your area how they too can get involved in fighting for the future of the travel agent industry by simply enlisting on the website www.TravelAgentsofAmerica.com.

Lawton Roberts
Founder, Travel Agents of America
Author, "Unfair At Any Fare"

Comment:
I am a travel agent, that wishes to comment on CRS rules. My main complaint is that online travel sites, particularly Orbitz, list air fares well below what an agent can sell. Since Orbitz is owned by the airlines, these Web fares are unfair and violate CRS contract rules.  For this reason, I am asking the DOT to subject online travel sites (particularly Orbitz) to the same CRS rules that the airline-owned CRSs have been required to follow. Orbitz, actual operations present competitive issues and I have a profound concern regarding the airline's practice of withholding lowest air fares not only from agents, but from anyone without access to a computer: I believe that all fares should be available, regardless of the technology used. It puts all agents in a very awkward situation, when a client informs us that they can acquire a lower airfare on the Internet. Also, I feel it is unethical to withhold these fares from those who are not computer savy. I have encountered an enormous loss of productivity in attempting to meet or beat the fares that my clients can acquire (on their own) by using the Internet. Furthermore, this creates confusion and distrust to the agent-client relationship. Please consider the impact that the Internet has had in airline distribution and extend the current CRS rules to to Internet.

Sincerely,
Aimee J. Ricca, Owner/Agent
Bonne Amie Travel

Title: Ashley S. Van Akker
Comment:
We are a C/TPA (Consortium/Third Party Administrator), and would like to comment on the current standards of SAP's.  Through numerous phone calls, endless searching on the web, and finally contacting the IC&RC and NAACAP via e-mail, we would like to encourage that the definition of an SAP be expanded to include state-licensed or certified professional counselors.  Trying to find a list of even three SAPs within the tri-city area should not take 7 days or longer.  The NAACAP responded to our e-mail with an internet address that sent us to a website that has not been updated since 11/20/2001, containing only one SAP name for the entire state of Michigan.  The other organization is getting back with us this week with some names of SAPs throughout Michigan.  
After calling multiple treatment centers throughout the state of Michigan, we have come to realize not many of them are familiar with this necessary certification, it seems to confuse them.  They either need to be informed of this certification, in detail, so they can help this industry, or the guidelines need to be widened.  Throught the attempt to explain to them what the Department of Transportation is, that there is an employee that failed a drug and/or alcohol screen, and they can only see Certified Substance Abuse Professionals should not confuse these centers, they should already know all about it, and more so than someone in our position.

Title: Kelly Kochanek
Comment:
Dear Mr. Secretary,

I am an Alaska Airlines employee and am writing to express support for the companys application for two "beyond-perimeter" slots between Ronald Reagan National Airport (DCA) and Los Angeles International Airport (LAX).

None of the current beyond-perimeter slot allocations are being used to serve California and approving our application would provide this badly needed convenient service. Approving our application would also provide "domestic network benefits" throughout the West Coast because together with our codeshare partners, we serve 43 domestic and international communities beyond Los Angeles.

Approving this application would also clearly "increase competition by new entrant air carriers." Although Alaska Airlines is a major presence on the West Coast, it currently has only two slots at DCAthe round-trip flight to Seattle-Tacoma International Airport (SEA) authorized by the Departments slot award last year.

Alaskas DCA-SEA service has been a big success and has resulted in more competitive fares between Seattle and all Washington-area airports. It has led to the initiation of our new service to other East Coast airports---Boston, Newark, Washington Dulles and Miami.

Most importantly from my perspective as an employee, allowing Alaska Airlines to fly to Washingtons Reagan National airport from LAX will best serve the public interest because of the award-winning customer service we will provide. We live our values of Alaska spirit, resourcefulness, integrity, professionalism and caring every day as we serve the traveling public.

Please allow us the opportunity to offer our unique customer service to travelers between LAX and DCA by granting Alaska Airlines the two available slots at Reagan National Airport. Thank you for your consideration.

Sincerely,
Kelly Kochanek

Title: Julie A. Christian
Comment:
RE:  OST-2000-8013
Respectfully submitted to the DOT:

I feel I must respond to this Central Time/Mountain Time issue once again.  

The arguments of "don't shove it down our throats," "our children won't survive," "it will ruin business in Mercer County" just don't hold water.  My three children have been living on Central Time their whole lives (they are 16, 13, and 10 years old) and are surviving quite fine!  

We live at Pick City and they go to school in Hazen; so, we are constantly doing the conversion, or asking "my time or your time," "Central Time or Mountain Time."  Yes, for a few short weeks in the winter we have shorter days which means on Central Time, children would go to school as the sun is coming up.  But conversely, on Mountain Time, they would be coming home from school as teh sun is going down!  I would rather that they be heading for school when the sun will soon be rising (school operating on Central Time) than coming home from school as the sun goes down and continues to get darker until the next day (school operating on Mountain Time).  And, really, this is for such a short time in the winter, I don't feel it is a major concern.

As for "ruining businesses by changing to Central Time, I believe Central Time would only benefit business.  In this day and age with technology etc., you need to do business with Bismarck, Minot, Fargo, maybe even Minneapolis.  They are all on Central Time.  You may try to contact one of these other business in the Central Time zone only to find out that they're on their lunch break (oops it's that darn time change again) or they're gone for the day (there goes that time change again).  It has to be very frustrating for businesses to constantly deal with this day in and day out.  Television and radio stations for this area are on Central Time (yes, Beulah does have a radio station - but that is ONE station versus the multiple ones from Bismarck and Minot that serve this area).  

We are a family of five.  My husband works in Beulah for one of the energy companies.  There are many power plants/energy companies in Mercer County.  They employ hundreds of people and the majority of these companies, if not all, operate on Central Time.  We are moving to Hazen in September.  The schools operate on Mountain Time; so, the kids and I will switch to Mountain Time.  My husband, who works at one of Mercer County's energy companies, will go to work on Central Time, which is the time most, if not all, of these companies operate on.  I hate to be blunt but, "it doesn't take a rocket scientist to figure this out!"  This is simply ridiculous!  Which clocks in my house shall I set to Central Time?  Which clocks shall I set to Mountain Time?  

Please, stop our confusion and let us all be on one time.  The only logical one is Central Time.  And yes, there was a vote, and the majority of that vote was for a change to Central Time!  Please, abide by this majority's decision of wanting to change to Central Time.  It just, simply, makes sense!! 

Julie Christian

February 25, 2002

Norman Y. Mineta, Secretary
United .States Department of Transportation
US DOT Dockets
Room PL-401
400 Seventh Street, SW

Attention:  Docket Clerk

Re:	Notice of Proposed Rulemaking
Reporting the Causes of Airline Delays and Cancellations
	Docket. No. OST 2000-8164


Dear Secretary Mineta:

The City of Boston Environment Department has reviewed the Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM) for Reporting the Causes of Airline Delays and Cancellations and hereby submits the following comments.

The City of Boston agrees with the Department of Transportation (DOT) and the Federal Advisory Air Carrier On-Time Task Force (Task Force) that changes in the current on-time reporting system are necessary in order that the public have clear information about the nature and sources of airline delays and cancellations.

The DOT is proposing that 14 CFR Part 234 be amended to require that airline carriers report the causes of airline delays and cancellations and that a new reporting requirement apply only to those air carriers already reporting under Part 234.  Small air carriers, medium and large regional air carriers, other major and national carriers and code-share partners of major carriers, accounting for 17 percent of enplanements, would not report data.  The inclusion of these carriers is to be the subject of a future rulemaking.  The NPRM recognizes that the absence of information from these carriers will potentially affect the utility of available information.

 BED Comments - Reporting the Causes of Airline Delays and Cancellations NPRM
Docket. No. OST 2000-8164
Page 2


Recommended in the NPRM are four categories for reporting delays:
h air carrier;
h extreme weather;
h National Aviation System (NAS); and
h late arriving aircraft.

Unclear from the list of activities to be attributed to air carrier-related and extreme weather-related delays is the assignment of deicing activities.  If deicing is considered maintenance, it would be under the air carrier category.  If it is attributed to extreme weather, it should be listed under the extreme weather category (delays caused by weather conditions, actual or forecasted at the point of departure, en route or at point of arrival that, in accordance with applicable regulatory standards and/or in the judgment of the air carrier, prevents operation of that flight and/or prevents operations of subsequent flights due to the intended aircraft being out of position as a result of a prior delay attributable to weather).

Bird strikes, coded as air carrier-related during a pilot program, may be more appropriately assigned to individual airports.  It appears that there is no such category unless airport-specific delays are assigned to the NAS category.

Given the significant and difficult changes in airport/airline security since the tragic events of September 11, 2001, we suggest that a separate security-related category may be helpful.  While we understand that the NAS category encompasses a number of operational eventualities, separating security-related delays from other operational events might aid the Department of Transportation (DOT) in determining the efficiency of new security procedures.

In discussing the NAS, the NPRM states that, Consistent high volume delays are an indication to airport operators and to state and local governments that there is a need for infrastructure investments and improvements.  We note that such investments and improvements need not occur at airports where there are high volume delays.  Consistent delays can signal an unbalanced regional air transportation system as suggested by the DOT/Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) Notice of Market-based Actions to Relieve Airport Congestion and Delay (Docket No. OST-2001-9849) through which the DOT sought Kinformation on the possible role, feasibility, and effectiveness of using market-based approaches to relieve airline flight delays and congestion at busy airports.   These approaches include peak period pricing, the auctioning of landing and takeoff rights and offering financial incentives and/or infrastructure investment to increase the use of 
BED Comments - Reporting the Causes of Airline Delays and Cancellations NPRM
Docket. No. OST 2000-8164
Page 3


secondary airports.  The City of Boston believes that the subject NPRM must be informed by the comments on OST-2001-9849 and policy around market-based actions to relieve congestion informed by the subject NPRM.

Without delay information from the 17 percent of carriers not required to report under this NPRM, it will be impossible for the DOT to implement well-informed market-based approaches to minimize delays.  In addition, some air carriers track the initial cause of a delay for late arriving aircraft and some do not.  Yet, the NPRM does not propose a standardized reporting system that would allow for the tracking of downline effects of earlier delays.  Giving carriers flexibility in this matter, consistent with the DOTs goal to require minimal change to the air carriers internal tracking systemsK hampers the collection of accurate data and makes delay assignment factually inadequate.  While we are sympathetic to the financial constraints of air carriers, delay reporting is not credible to the public and not useful to policy-makers when consistent data is not collected from all carriers.  The City of Boston suggests that mandated, standardized reporting required of all carriers operating in the U.S. is necessary in order to gather precise and truly useful data.

Thank you for the opportunity to offer comment.


Sincerely,



Antonia M. Pollak
Director

The safety association of the commercial explosives industry.  Founded 1913

February 28, 2002



Dockets Management System
U.S. Department of Transportation
Room PL-401

Re:	Docket Number OST-01-10380; Hazardous Materials: Knowledge Requirement of Civil Penalty Enforcement Proceedings (66 Fed. Reg. 42909)

Dear Sir or Madam:

On behalf of the Institute of Makers of Explosives (IME), I am submitting comments on the issues covered by the above-captioned notice.  

The IME is the safety association of the commercial explosives industry.  Our mission is to promote safety and the protection of employees, users, the public and the environment; and to encourage the adoption of uniform rules and regulations in the manufacture, transportation, storage, handling, use and disposal of explosive materials used in blasting and other essential operations.  IME member companies produce over 95 percent of the commercial explosives consumed in the United States.  IME member companies regularly engage in transporting hazardous materials and/or arranging for the transportation of such materials.  Accordingly, the issues covered by this proceeding have significant interest to IME.

IME supports the request submitted by Federal Express Corporation (Federal Express) that the Department of Transportation (DOT) develop further guidance regarding what constitutes constructive knowledge under the Hazardous Materials Transportation Act (Pub. L. 93-633, 110, 88 Stat. 2160 (Jan. 3, 1975).  Specifically, Federal Express has requested DOT to provide additional guidance providing essential criteria defining constructive knowledge of undeclared hazardous materials, that would allow the carriers to design and implement a viable system for training their employees and for identifying and reporting discrepancies .  66 Fed. Reg. 42910.

1120 Nineteenth Street, N.W., Suite 310, Washington, D.C.  20036-3605  Tel:  (202) 429-9280
 

The Federal Register notice describing the Federal Express proposal notes that the Research and Special Programs Administration (RSPA) considers a carrier to have knowingly violated the Hazardous Materials Regulations (HMR) when the carrier accepts or transports a hazardous material with actual or constructive knowledge that a package contains a hazardous material which has not been packaged, marked, labeled, and described on a shipping paper as required by the HMR.  Id. at 42910.  The legal standard remains that knowledge that a reasonable person acting in the circumstances and exercising reasonable care would have.  Id.   IME agrees with Federal Express that guidance providing greater specificity regarding what constitutes reasonable care and constructive knowledge will assist carriers in understanding their obligations under the law and in complying with the HMR.

As DOT is undoubtedly well aware, the question of whether the circumstances of a particular case are sufficient to give rise to an obligation of further inquiry often is fraught with appreciable difficulty  both for the carrier and DOT.  To the extent that DOT is able to outline a set of facts that will, in ordinary circumstances, be expected to trigger further inquiry on the part of a carrier, both the carrier and the DOT inspector will be better able to determine whether the actions of the carrier are/were appropriate to a given situation.

Likewise, IME agrees with Federal Express that providing guidance as to what types of documentation will not be reviewed, and, therefore, will not give rise to a claim of constructive knowledge, also will benefit carriers and DOT inspectors.  Because constructive knowledge is imputed only to those facts that are reasonably and naturally connected to a known fact and to which the known fact furnishes a clue, it is critical to understand that certain types of documentation will not be considered in determining what facts are known to a carrier and whether those facts should have spurred further investigation.  

Specifically, if a carrier has no legal or other obligation to review MSDS sheets, commercial invoices, packing sheets, etc. accompanying a shipment, it would be unreasonable to hold it responsible for gleaning facts or clues in those documents regarding the nature or content of a particular shipment.  Including a list of such documents in a guidance document would provide much needed clarification to carriers and DOT officials regarding the scope of the carriers obligation to inspect and investigate shipments placed in their hands.  No duty [to inquire] can exist without knowledge of the facts  upon which such duty rests.  58 Am Jur 2d 9.  

Similarly, carriers should not be imputed with constructive knowledge in cases where only broad, generic and ambiguous terms such as paint, chemical, this-end-up, fragile, caution, cold, UN, DOT, IMO, ICAO, or IATA, without further indicia of hazard, are used by the offeror of the shipment.  See, Federal Express Comments, February 28, 2002, page 3.

While IME supports the development of a guidance document, we also acknowledge that it is impossible  to lay down a general rule by which to determine what facts are sufficient to excite inquiry.  58 Am Jur 2d 11.  It seems clear, however, that Federal Express is not requesting DOT to prepare an exhaustive list of what information will or will not confer constructive knowledge in every circumstance.  Rather, the carrier industry is requesting DOTs continued assistance in helping the industry to better appreciate the types of information that DOT considers telling and/or suspect and, so, to help the industry devise more targeted and effective training programs to identify potential undeclared shipments of hazardous goods.  In this regard, IME is wholly supportive of the request made by Federal Express.

Your consideration of these comments is appreciated.

Sincerely,

sig

Susan J.P. Flanagan 
Counsel

Re:	Docket No. OST-01-10380: Knowledge required for Civil Penalty Enforcement Proceedings


Dear Sir or Madam:

	E. I. DuPont de Nemours and Company (DuPont) is a global science and technology company engaged in the manufacture, sale and distribution of chemicals, crop protection products, paints, textiles, resins, plastics and related materials.  Many of the products produced by DuPont or purchased by it are regulated by the Department of Transportation (DOT) and fall within the definition of hazardous materials as that term is defined in the hazardous materials regulations (HMR) found in the United Stated Code of Federal Regulations (CFR).  DuPont is grateful for the opportunity to share its experience and comment on the Notice and Invitation to Comment referenced above.

	DuPont is vitally interested in ensuring that its products and those it purchases are transported safely and in full compliance with all applicable law.  To accomplish this task DuPont maintains a hazardous material consultants group in its core and, over 25 years ago, established its RHYTHM (Remember How You Treat Hazardous Materials) network of knowledgeable and trained hazmat employees within its strategic business units and at all manufacturing and warehouse locations.  Annual meetings and periodic in-house training sessions are conducted for its hazmat employees.  In addition, employees are encouraged to attend outside hazmat training courses affecting areas or products within the scope of their employment.  DuPont also actively shares information concerning United States and international regulatory requirements and safe transportation practices with customers and suppliers throughout DuPonts global supply chain.

	Despite all the attention and resources dedicated to the training of its employees and others throughout its corporate supply chain, DuPont will, from time to time, receive shipments of raw materials, samples or returns which are not properly documented, marked, labeled, placarded or packaged in accordance with applicable hazardous materials regulations.  Investigation of these incidents has indicated that, as a rule, these incidents result either from negligence on the part of one or more employees or lack of knowledge on the part of the shipper or its employees.  The later case is more prevalent with overseas shipments than with those that originating within the United States.  Many of these incidents are brought to DuPonts attention by its able carrier partners.


	DuPont is also aware that, from time to time, unscrupulous shippers will purposefully tender undeclared hazardous materials to unsuspecting carriers for transport.  Whether this is done to avoid the added costs of compliance with the HMR, to avoid higher freight cost or for some other inappropriate reason, this practice is wrong and should be stopped.  Shippers, in cases involving willful and purposeful violation of the HMR, should be prosecuted  both civilly and criminally - and punished.  Cases involving conscience and willful misconduct, however, should be separated from instances where ,due to simple negligence or lack of knowledge, the HMR are violated.  DuPont will in the balance of its statement confine its comments to situations involving simple negligence or lack of sophistication on the part of shippers engaged in the distribution of hazardous materials.

Carriers, regardless of mode, are the last line of defense in protecting the public from the undeclared or improperly prepared shipments of hazardous materials.  Each carrier, therefore, should, and in DuPonts judgement has a legal obligation, not to accept for transport any regulated materials that are not properly marked, labeled, placarded, packaged or documented in accordance with applicable regulations..  

	As indicated in comments by the American Trucking Association in this proceeding, the HMR currently provides that the DOT may assess a civil penalty against a person that knowingly violates the law.  It further states that: 

		A person acts knowingly when  

(A) The person has actual knowledge of the facts giving rise to the violation; or
(B) A reasonable person acting in the circumstances and exercising reasonable care would have that knowledge. 

In 1998 The Research and Special Programs Administrations (RSPA) Chief Counsel offered the following guidance for use in interpreting this section of the HMR:

 (A) Carrier may not ignore readily apparent facts that indicate that either (1) a shipment declared to contain a hazardous material is not properly packaged, marked, labeled, placarded or described on a shipping paper, or (2) a shipment actually contains a hazardous material governed by the HMR despite the fact that it is not marked, labeled placarded or described on a shipping paper as containing a hazardous material .

In the case of an undeclared or hidden shipment, all relevant facts must be considered to determine whether or not a reasonable person acting in the circumstances and exercising reasonable care would realize the presence of hazardous materials . 

A carriers  employees who accept packages for transportation must be trained to recognize a suspicious package as part of their function-specific training as specified in 49 CFR 172.704(a)(2), because the legal standard remains the knowledge of a reasonable person acting in the circumstances and exercising reasonable care would have. 

	Based upon this interpretation and advice, carriers must exercise reasonable care in their acceptance of packages or other freight.  If freight offered for transport manifests an inconstancy in its offering, the carrier should question the shipper and resolve the discrepancy before accepting the freight for transport.  Inconsistencies might include the presence of hazardous materials labels or placards but the absence of appropriate shipping papers or the inclusion of a hazardous materials description on a shipping paper accompanying materials lacking labels or placards.  Similarly, if words, such as those set out on page two of comments submitted on behalf of Federal Express on February 28, 2002 are contained within the text of the shipping papers or other documents generally reviewed by the carrier in the normal course of accepting freight for transport, the carrier should not accept the material for transport.  If, under these circumstances, undeclared hazardous materials are accepted by the carrier for transport, the carrier should be liable for a fine for not acting as a reasonable carrier would (or should) act under the circumstances.

	Prudence would also indicate that a carrier exercising reasonable care, which has repeatedly been offered hazardous materials from a given shipper, should hesitate to accept packages from that same shipper which possess the same characteristics as those it has historically received but are not marked, labeled or otherwise documented as containing hazardous materials.  Prudence and public interest would indicate that the carrier, in such circumstance, should ask the shipper if it has made an error or if this is a different product from those it has historically been tendered.  Failure to do so would constitute a failure to act with reasonable care and should subject the carrier to a civil fine or other appropriate punishment.

	Prudence would also dictate that the carrier should have a notice process for use when dealing with new and/or unsophisticated shippers to ensure that they are aware of and can adequately fulfill their obligations under the HMR.  Simple inquiries of these shippers made prior to their initial shipments about the contents and preparation of the packages should be made.  Such inquires could parallel the questions raised by check in clerks for passenger at the airports.  Such inquiries should continue to be made until the carrier is comfortable that the shipper has sufficient knowledge to properly fulfill its obligations under the HMR.  This practice would parallel a similar obligation imposed upon importers of hazardous materials (dangerous goods) to ensure that their overseas suppliers are aware of all applicable hazardous materials (dangerous goods) regulations.

In addition, signs, similar in nature to those posted in passenger airports, should be posted in receiving areas for LTL, package and other carriers who receive small shipments at a central location away from the shippers principal place of business or  residence..  Written notices informing new or sporadic shippers of the existence and nature of the HMR, perhaps including the definitions of the hazard classes, should also be provided by carriers.

	Carriers, as the publics last defense, should, and DuPont believes do, have an obligation to make a reasonable, affirmative effort to protect the public from improper or unauthorized shipment of hazardous materials which can result in spills and other incidents.  This effort should be in addition to the obligations of shippers to properly prepare, package, label, placard and document hazardous materials shipments.  Failure to exercise reasonable care to protect the public in such cases should result in fines or other penalties.  The duty to act with reasonable care should apply equally to all  including shippers and carriers - of those involved in the distribution of hazardous materials.

	The DOT should assist this effort by helping to better define minimum obligations which carriers, shippers and others engaged in the distribution of hazardous materials, owe the public and which would be imposed upon them under RSPAs definition of constructive knowledge.  The practices which DuPont has suggested above as well as those referenced by Federal Express, if codified and included in appropriate rulemakings or other guidelines, would help define what these minimum obligations are and further enhance the safe transportation of hazardous materials which shippers, carriers and the DOT owe to the public.  

				Very truly yours,



				William A. McCurdy
				Logistics and Commerce Counsel

Title: Richard B. Rooney
Comment:
Our company while operating as an air taxi under Part 135 is primarily an air tour operator.  We are supportive of the Department using its discretion to provide a set-aside for air ambulances, air tour operators and others for whom the ASM-based formula inadequately reflects their share of direct and incremental losses incurred in the post 9/11 period.

Many air tour operations were heavily injured in the post 9/11 period because in addition to their revenues being derived from discretionary expenditures by customers they are located in areas dependent on air carrier travel for the customer to get to the locality in the first place such as Hawaii.  This is in effect a double whammy.  Furthermore, costs per ASM are generally much higher due to the smaller aircraft utilized in air tour operations.  My calculations indicate that we may receive compensation from the Department under the current program equal to only about 15 percent of our projected losses as submitted.  I doubt that many, if any, of the scheduled carriers are receiving anywhere near that small a percentage of their losses.

The Department in its Federal Register Request for Comments stated that they had little information about the situation of air carriers other than air ambulances to which a set-aside could apply.  On the contrary, they already have significant data about them from the "second increment" submissions seeking compensation.  All that may be missing is identifying which carriers fall into particular groups.  That should be easily solved with an identification request to air taxi "second increment" submitters.

Much emphasis has been placed on compensating under the ASM approach regularly reported upon by the scheduled carriers to the Department.  However, the Department has required all claiming carriers whether scheduled, cargo or air taxi to also report "common" data detailing losses and projected losses for the same applicable periods.  From that data, the Department should already know the projected losses of all submitting carriers and can compute the expected average percentage compensation payout on projected losses.

Seems to me that the Department simply needs only to identify the air tour and air ambulance carriers, and then analyze the data already submitted in  order to determine the magnitude to which these carriers were more injured than the average.  The goal of this whole program should be to provide some equality, though certainly not perfect, in loss percentage coverage among all the submitting carriers.  A set-aside should be carved out of the 4.5 billion to satisfy that objective.  Its size should be determinable by the foregoing method of analysis of existing data after identifying the appropriate members of the group.

Title: Todd A. Hunter
Comment:
The criteria for determining which carriers need apply full Agreed Upon Procedures, (AUPs) and those that apply simplified procedures should not be based on ASMs or RTMs but rather the materiality of the loss reimbursement requested.  The current methodology could require a carrier that has a certain level of ASMs or RTMs perform full AUPs when the carriers actual loss reimbursement is relatively small.  This could unfairly burden the carrier despite the difference in claim size.

Based on distributions to date through April 2, 2002, and the information published in the Federal Register on April 16, 2002, assuming the top 97 distributions, as of April 2, 2002, were the 97 carriers required to perform full AUPs, as estimated in the Federal Register, carriers that received approximately $130,000 to $5,000,000 would be required to apply the same procedures as a carrier that received $100,000,000 to $644,000,000.  If you take the top 25 carriers distributions, 93.8 percent of all the dollars distributed to date are covered.  Alternatively, taking carriers that have distributions in excess of $10,000,0000, 95.5 percent of all the dollars distributed to date are covered.   Obviously, after the final distributions have been made the numbers will change but the magnitude of the differences and the percentage covered will likely be the same.  As noted in the Federal Register on April 16, 2002, there is a very significant difference in the amount of estimated time to complete the AUP and simplified procedures.  The AUPs are estimated to take 38 and 120 times the amount of effort the first and second tier-simplified procedures will take.  Accordingly, it is not fair to burden carriers that have requested a relatively very small amount of loss reimbursement with the same reporting and procedures as those carriers that have requested tens or even hundreds of millions of dollars.  It is reasonable to assume the resources of the carriers in the lower portion of the current AUP requirement, based on RTM and ASM, have nowhere near the resources of the carriers that have received tens or hundreds of millions of dollars.

In summary, the criteria for determining the requirement to perform full AUP versus simplified procedures should be modified.  The determination should be based on the materiality of the requested loss reimbursement and not the ASMs or RTM.  Additionally, the AUP requirement should take the relative size of the requested loss reimbursement into consideration.  The same level of reporting should not be required by carriers who have requested less than $10 million as by carriers who have requested in excess of $100 million.

Based on distributions to date through April 2, 2002, and the information published in the Federal Register on April 16, 2002, assuming the top 97 distributions, as of April 2, 2002, were the 97 carriers required to perform full AUPs, as estimated in the Federal Register, carriers that received approximately $130,000 to $5,000,000 would be required to apply the same procedures as a carrier that received $100,000,000 to $644,000,000.  If you take the top 25 carriers distributions, 93.8 percent of all the dollars distributed to date are covered.  Alternatively, taking carriers that have distributions in excess of $10,000,0000, 95.5 percent of all the dollars distributed to date are covered.   Obviously, after the final distributions have been made the numbers will change but the magnitude of the differences and the percentage covered will likely be the same.  As noted in the Federal Register on April 16, 2002, there is a very significant difference in the amount of estimated time to complete the AUP and simplified procedures.  The AUPs are estimated to take 38 and 120 times the amount of effort the first and second tier-simplified procedures will take.  Accordingly, it is not fair to burden carriers that have requested a relatively very small amount of loss reimbursement with the same reporting and procedures as those carriers that have requested tens or even hundreds of millions of dollars.  It is reasonable to assume the resources of the carriers in the lower portion of the current AUP requirement, based on RTM and ASM, have nowhere near the resources of the carriers that have received tens or hundreds of millions of dollars.

In summary, the criteria for determining the requirement to perform full AUP versus simplified procedures should be modified.  The determination should be based on the materiality of the requested loss reimbursement and not the ASMs or RTM.  Additionally, the AUP requirement should take the relative size of the requested loss reimbursement into consideration.  The same level of reporting should not be required by carriers who have requested less than $10 million as by carriers who have requested in excess of $100 million.

RE: Procedures for Compensation of Air Carriers

Dear Secretary Mineta,

I am the Edward R. Eroe of the Duke Life Flight, a hospital-based helicopter service that serves Central North Carolina, Southern Virginia, and Northern South Carolina.  Duke operates two helicopters with over 1,200 transports for cardiac, trauma, neo-natal, and other critical patients. 

The federal closing of our nations airspace as a result of the attacks of September 11th, 2001, created financial hardship for my air ambulance operations. This was due to not being able to fly for nearly two days and then seeing a decrease in requests from referring hospitals thinking that we could not fly due to the terrorist attacks.  I am writing to request that the Department of Transportation provide reimbursement for our operation so it can continue serving the critically ill and injured individuals in our community.  

Unfortunately, the DOTs  Procedures for Compensation of Air Carriers notice published in the Federal Register on April 17, 2002, does not provide an effective mechanism for us to apply for this sorely needed relief.  In fact, we believe that this notice does not meet the intent of Congress amendment to the Aviation and Transportation Security Act (Public Law 107-71), which recognized that air ambulances are a unique and essential type of air carrier that cannot be treated in the same manner as other air carriers. This amendment clearly stated that some relief monies could be set-aside for air ambulances and other air carriers for whom application of a distribution formula containing available seat miles as a factor would inadequately reflect their share of direct and incremental costs.  Yet, the DOT notice again mistakenly ties air ambulance reimbursement to an Average Seat Mile (ASM) formula which Congress has acknowledged is inadequate for gauging air ambulance revenue losses. (ASMs are not, and never have been reported to the Department by air ambulance operations.)  In fact, your notice seems to condition air ambulance reimbursement on the reporting of ASMs, leading our organization to question whether air ambulances are even eligible to apply for relief under this notice.
 
Even if we were eligible to apply, application of ASMs to air ambulance operations as per the DOT notice will reimburse air ambulances at a rate of less than 1% of its average revenues per patient transport.  How can this be fair when the Part 121 carriers have been earmarked to receive 65% or more of their lost revenues?

We ask that the Department reconsider its procedures for compensation of air ambulances. We understand that the Association of Air Medical Services offered a reasonable mechanism for providing relief through the use of the average patient transport costs under the Medicare fee schedule. This Medicare per trip rate represents 63% of normal single-transport or per-trip revenues.

The civilian air medical industry provides over ninety percent of the medical airlift capacity in this country, and plays a critical role in responding to all kinds of emergencies. Appropriate compensation to help maintain our nations emergency response infrastructure is of paramount importance, now more than ever. 

Sincerely,



Edward R. Eroe, M.H.S.A., CHE, CAE, CMTE
Associate Operating Officer, Emergency Services
Program Director, Duke Life Flight

Title: Rahul L. Iyer
Comment:
Concerning improvements in the USA air travel system, I hope that the FAA and related agencies make note of the following.  In the Chicago area, and other parts of the Midwest (including St Louis), there are many smaller airports that are under-utilized while airports like Chicago O'Hare or St Louis Lambert just get more and more crowded and congested.  Chicago Midway Airport is already at capacity.  This leads to flight delays.  

Perhaps, concerning Chicago, it is time to look at other airports in the region.  This includes Rockford (Illinois), and Gary (Indiana).  Both of these airports are underutilized and have a lot of room to expand should it be necessary.

For St Louis, there is Mid-America Airport on the Illinois side, that is currently and expensive, under-utilized boondoggle right now.  St Louis Lambert Airport is already at capacity.  

How can the airlines and regulators encourage better utilization of existing airports?  Here are my suggestions:

1) At peak times raise the fees charged for flights into places like Chicago O'Hare or St Louis Lambert.

2)  Through a mandate of some sort, cap the number of flights that can land in a specified length of time at places like O'Hare or Lambert.

3) Encourage airlines to start offering comparable flights to other regional airports in the same vicinity in order to keep the same number of flights, if not increase, to a particular metropolitan area.  

4)  Figure out ways make flights originating or arriving at say Chicago-Gary Airport, instead of Chicago O'Hare competitive in regard to service and cost.  This can be done, as supposedly under-utilized airports like Chicago-Gary, Rockford (Illinois), and perhaps even St Louis Mid-America, have lower operation costs, landing fees, and security costs associated with their use.  

I am also sure that various types of tax holidays can be implemented for places like Chicago-Gary, or Rockford (Illinois), as many of these under-utilized airports are in economically depressed areas and would benefit from such an expansion when it comes to jobs and economy.  Hopefully, these types of tax holidays will reflect also in the prices for air-tickets from these airports, provided that it is properly structured.

5) And lastly, particularly for the Chicago metropolitan area, some of the under-utilized airports need to be better connected into the local travel network, so that people landing in say Chicago O'Hare can use bus or rail to get to either Rockford or Chicago-Gary to catch a connecting flight.  If we just leave the road system as is, then we have just replaced an air congestion problem with a road congestion problem...primarily in the vicinity of the airports.  There should be alternative forms of transport between airports in a given metropolitan area. 

Some other comments that I have concerning this include the following observations.  

Rockford (Illinois) and Gary (Indiana) have experienced high job losses as many of their traditional industries have closed.  Expanding their under-utilized airports would provide a real "shot in the arm" to the local economy when it comes to jobs and economic development.

Also, for the case of Rockford (Illinois), the immediate area around the airport is predominantly rural cornfields, which means that the increase in aircraft noise will not necessarily adversely affect the quality of life for the people living in that vicinity.

For Gary (Indiana), the airport is located in the middle of an industrial zone, which is already noisy, so that is not a problem.  Also, most of the land available for airport expansion is brown fields which is pretty much useless except for other industrial developments or something like and airport.  Any of the so called people that will be displaced are the ones who are are living on the abandoned properties illegally, and they should not be there in the first place.

Title: Jeffrey Neil Jones
Comment: To level out the demand-related peaks of congestion, I think that the use of Peak/Off Peak charges on each plane, perhaps varying by airport where appropriate, would be good market-based initiatives to thoroughly investigate, among others.  This might produce air quality, land use and environmental justice benefits in many instances. There may arise specific situations or sites in which keeping track of the percentage occupancy of flights, particularly of large commercial carriers is a desirable means for managing congestion. This peak charge system would be best employed as a well-publicized responsive pricing, or variable pricing system, that reflects the marginal cost of usage at the most intense daily, weekly, monthly and seasonal/holiday peak periods.  This marginal cost is of course partly the delay to others who do or would have used the facility, passengers and carriers alike. I believe that DOT could balance the practical need for carriers to know price in advance, with the greater effectiveness of more variable, or congestion responsive charges.  I propose that prices be calculated or advertised as a schedule of ranges of possible prices depending on time of day or season. Another approach charges flight departures (and conceivably of arrivals) by mimicing an idealized form of automotive HOV/HOT lane: Very full planes could be charged less than very empty planes on a staggered or proportionately increasing fee structure. Or just require that fuller planes pay less, and let the airlines decide whether they are willing to implement things like William Vickrey's market-based ideas for marginal cost ticket pricing, i.e., a "speculative 'futures market' for ticket sales," or some other method.  See Vickrey's Public Economics, p252-268.

Title: SCAG Aviation Staff
Comment:
Memorandum
 
Date:	May 21, 2002 
To:	Aviation Technical Advisory Committee
From:	 SCAG Aviation Staff
RE:	Comments on Market-Based Solutions to Relieve Airport Congestion and Delay 
The U.S. Department of Transportation is soliciting comments on possible market-based actions to relieve airport congestion and delay.  These actions, published in the August 21, 2001 Federal Register are designed to reduce delays, improve airport capacity management, enhance competition and promote the efficiency of the overall aviation system.  The proposed actions were prompted by the unprecedented flight delays that had plagued the national aviation system, prior to the recent economic downturn and the events of September 11.  They cover these four basic categories:  
 Auctions, which would allocate a fixed number of operations for some particular period of time.
 Congestion pricing, which would which would charge air carriers not only for the costs they impose on an airport, but also the delay costs they impose on other airport users.
 Peak-period pricing, which would impose fees based on the higher costs and airport incurs to accommodate demand during peak hours, or the cost an airport does not incur because flights are shifted from busy periods of the day to less busy periods.
 Flat fees, which would restructure exiting weigh-based landing fees so that total airfield costs are recovered through a higher average fee, thereby affecting the mix of aircraft that operate at an airport. 
All of these market-based approaches are aimed at achieving a better balance between supply and demand in the aviation industry, mainly by using airport facilities more than they otherwise would during off-peak periods, and reduce the bunching of flights during peak periods.  To the extent that options are available in a regional system, these actions could also provide inducements to airlines to shift service to less congested alternate airports with lower fee structures.  
There are a number of questions and issues on these proposed actions that the FAA notice poses and requests comments on.  They do not cover legal issues such as potential conflict with current federal aviation law; it is requested that responders set aside consideration of current statutory or regulatory issues in their comments.  The question and issues posed (22 total) cover these basic categories, which are relevant to regional aviation planning:
 Application of market-based actions: Which specific market-based mechanisms are most promising?  Why?  How should policymakers decide which airports might benefit from the imposition of market-based approaches, and which factors should they consider in making these decisions, such as available capacity, current flight volumes, capacity expansion initiatives, etc.?  
 Performance standards: What level of delay is acceptable at airports after the imposition of market-based approaches?  Should all delay be eliminated?  How much would user charges have to be increased to shift or reduce demand to meet delay targets?  How would you calculate fees that are based on expansive concept of delay-related costs, including the value of lost time to travelers? How would random factors be taken into account that impact delay, such as weather?  How would approaches be designed to accommodate unexpected demand shifts?  What data is needed to measure the effectiveness of market-based mechanisms?  
 Surplus revenues: Given that market-based fees could result in airports receiving revenues in excess of their operating and capital costs, should these surplus revenues be used to enhance capacity at the capacity constrained airport, at another airport that is part of the proprietors system, or elsewhere in the aviation system?  How do you determine where, how much and what type of new airport capacity is needed in terms of using surplus revenues?  How would you implement the use of surplus revenues on a systemwide basis?  
 Secondary airports: Will market-based approaches to airport access increase the use of less-congested secondary airports?  Should airports in the same region that are not under the same ownership have the ability to promote the use underused airports? 
 Aircraft size and fleet mix: Will market-based approaches encourage or discourage the operation of certain types of aircraft?  Should they be crafted to encourage airlines to operate large aircraft, maximizing the number of seats per operation?  
 Potential impacts: Would adoption of market-based approaches adversely impact airfares, new entrants, airline competition, hub-and-spoke networks, service to small communities, general aviation, and international air services?  How could such potential adverse impacts be mitigated, such as using differential pricing or exempting certain user categories?  What would be the potential economic benefits/cost savings to airlines, airports and surrounding communities? 
Comments
Following are some suggested comments developed by SCAG aviation staff that can be made that respond to the questions and issues posed above, which are relevant to current and pressing aviation-related issues in the SCAG Region.
1. The SCAG regional airport system is a potential candidate for the fruitful application of market-based approaches to relieve airport congestion and delay.  Our one international hub airport, Los Angeles International (LAX), was one of the most delay-plagued airports in the country before the events of September 11.  At just 3500 acres it is one of the smallest international hub airports in the country, and has little room to expand without causing excessive environmental impacts on surrounding communities.  Yet the region also has a number of underutilized secondary airport in outlying areas that can absorb increased demand.  The lack of airline investments in these airports has been the main stumbling block in decentralizing demand away from our congested urban airports.  
2. Market-based mechanisms, if effective, have the potential to make better use of limited capacity at LAX by spreading demand to off-peak periods, and by inducing airline interest in secondary airports that have substantially lower peak period fee structures than LAX.  It should be noted that a number of secondary airports in the region, including Burbank, Long Beach and John Wayne airports, are all very small and have little room to accommodate future passenger and cargo growth.  Long Beach Airport is subject to a legally enforceable capacity constraint of 41 air carrier flights per day.  Also, Burbank and John Wayne are currently limited by terminal gate capacity, which does not necessarily cause flight delays as does limited runway capacity.
3. The existing physical capacity of LAX is limited by its available runway capacity.  Since no major capacity expansions are currently being planned, when demand recovers in the near future, increasing flight delays at LAX will likely recur.  Market-based mechanisms therefore have potential for making better use of the available runway capacity at LAX in lieu of major runway capacity improvements. However, regional aviation demand modeling that SCAG has conducted over the last ten years indicates that there is a limit to which passengers will accept traveling during off-peak hours, particularly business travelers, even when substantially lower airfares are offered.  Without another large international hub airport in the region, there is also a limit to which international passengers can be diverted to smaller secondary airports in the region that lack the connecting traffic that it needed to support substantial international service to multiple global destinations.  Further, there is a limit to which market based strategies can induce the transition to fleets with larger aircraft at LAX.  This transition is ultimately governed by the ability of the aircraft manufacturing industry to produce new generation aircraft, and the ability of the airline industry to economically amortize their investments in existing aircraft.  It is expected that as LAX reached its capacity constraints, there will be a natural incentive for carriers to use the largest available aircraft in order to carry as many passengers as possible given limitations on flights in the face of growing demand.  
4. Airport-related costs are only about 3-4% of total airline costs.  Landing fees would have to be raised substantially at LAX in order to change airline behavior in terms of inducing them to move service to off-peak periods or alternate secondary airports with far less economies of scale than LAX (but also much less congestion).  The revenue generated would likely be far in excess of what is need to operate, maintain and improve LAX. The public agency that runs LAX, Los Angeles World Airports, also manages two alternate airports: Ontario and Palmdale, to which surplus revenue could be diverted for capacity and enhancements.  However, it has no jurisdiction over three secondary airports in the region with room to expand that could be the beneficiary of the surplus revenues generated: March Global Port, San Bernardino International, and Southern California Logistics airports.  A recently reactivated Southern California Regional Airport Authority (SCRAA) could be an institutional vehicle for deciding how surplus revenues generated by market-based approaches are equitably allocated among airports in the SCAG region.  The SCRAA would need to be substantially reorganized and redirected to accomplish this task however; it currently does not enjoy region-wide support of its current agenda, which is fairly ambiguous.  Efforts by the SCRAA to become a regional broker of airport-generated revenues would likely meet with stiff resistance from the local airport authorities that would generate surplus revenues.  
5. The use of surplus funds generated by market based approaches should not be restricted to just the funding of airport capacity expansion projects.  Consideration should be given to making off-airport ground access projects that primarily serve air travelers and air cargo, and off-airport environmental mitigation projects such as noise retrofit programs, eligible as well.  New standards and criteria would need to be developed for defining permissible uses of surplus funds. 
6. On-airport benefits of market-based strategies should not be limited to just congestion relief.   Consideration should be given to basing fees, at least in part, on air and noise emissions, with lower fees granted to aircraft with engines that emit lower air and noise emissions levels.  The importance of emission fees relative to congestion fees could vary depending on measured noise and air quality impacts on surrounding communities versus total traffic levels.  For example, an airport that handled relatively low levels of traffic but had disproportionately high environmental impacts on surrounding communities would place a much higher relative importance on air and noise emissions per aircraft in setting fees.  Small urban airports in the SCAG Region, such as Burbank, Long Beach and John Wayne, that experience relatively low levels of aircraft congestion but inflict relatively high amount of environmental impacts per aircraft operation on surrounding communities would be prime candidates for this type of market-based approach.  It should be noted that currently there is little or no incentive for airlines to install pollution control retrofit devices on their engines, even through those devices have proven to be very cost effective in reducing largely uncontrolled emissions such as nitrous oxides.  There is also little incentive for airlines to change their current practice of installing hush kit equipment on old aircraft engines that allow them to just barely meet federal noise standards, instead of re-engining their aircraft with the latest engine technology that reduces aircraft noise levels far below current standards.  Zurich Airport in Switzerland is an example of airport that has successfully implemented a market-based emission fee program, and has enjoyed cleaner and quieter aircraft operations as a result. 
7. There are many questions and issues posed by the Notice that simply cannot be answered in any definitive manner due to a lack of evidence and data.  These include which market based measures are most promising, which factors should decision makers consider in applying the measure, how much delay is acceptable, how high should fees be set to reach desired levels of delay, what criteria should fees be based on, and what data is needed to measure effectiveness of measures?  They also ask how do you make the measures flexible, what would be the impacts on small communities and international service, would they increase the use of less congested secondary airports, and what would be the potential cost savings and benefits to airlines, airports and local communities?  Case studies and pilot programs need to be conducted in order to establish an information base, derived from actual experience, which can be used to help answer these and other questions.   It is suggested that the SCAG regional airport system provides a wide variety of airport types and aviation issues, and would be a good testing ground for evaluating the effectiveness of market-based actions in reducing congestion and delay, and reducing environmental impacts of airports on local communities.  SCAG has developed and employed state-of-the-art modeling tools, such as the RADAM airport demand allocation model, that could be used to evaluate the effectiveness of market-based actions on a regional basis.
